titleStmt.title: Two letters sent from the Lord Inchiqueen, unto the Speaker of the Honourable House of Commons. Concerning two great victories obtained over the rebels in Ireland. With an order from the House, that letters of thanks should be returned unto the Lord Inchiqueen. Die Martis, 18 Maii, 1647. Ordered by the Commons assembled in Parliament, that these letters of the Lord Inchiqueen's be forthwith printed and published. Hen. Elsynge Cler. Parl. Dom. Com.
titleStmt.author: Inchiquin, Murrough O'Brien, Earl of, 1614-1674.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Campaigns -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: TWO LETTERS SENT From the Lord INCHIQUEEN, Unto the SPEAKER of the Honourable Hou≈øe of COMMONS.
Concerning two great Victories obtained over the REBELS in IRELAND.
With an Order from the Hou≈øe, that Letters of Thanks ≈øhould be returned unto the LORD INCHIQUEEN.
ORdered by the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, That the≈øe Letters of the Lord INCHIQUEEN'S be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øynge Cler. Parl. Dom. Com.

div.p: London, Printed for John Wright, at the Kings Head in the Old-baily. 1647.

ON Frday la≈øt Dromannagh was ≈øurrendred into my hands, having fir≈øt made a ≈ømall breach in their Outwork, and falling on with ≈øome men; upon that the rebels retreated into the Ca≈øtle, which indeed was a place that might have held out a long time: but having gained the Town-wall, and drawn up our Ordnance again≈øt it, the rogues took quarter for life and wearing apparel onely, and left all things el≈øe, which were not valuable, they having long expected a ≈øiege: ≈øo as the be≈øt booty there was 4 barrels of powder, with a proportion of match, a ≈ømal piece of Ordnance, a Murderer, 2 ≈øling-pieces, and 100 Arms (but the gard were not above 60 men at mo≈øt). From thence I ≈øent away the Hor≈øe in≈øtantly to face Cappoquin, and ju≈øt as they drew up before the town, there was a ≈øupply of powder and match coming, with three Troops of Hor≈øe, and a Regiment of Foot, who pre≈øently retreated with all the ha≈øt they could to Clomnell in ≈øight of our Hor≈øe; ≈øo as when I came with the re≈øt of the Army to beleager the place; they conde≈øcended at the fir≈øt ≈øummons to treat, and (as afterwards appeared for want of Ammunition) to give up the place upon the inclo≈øed Articles: Ju≈øt as the town was given up to mee, I had adverti≈øment of the landing of Col. Temple, with upwards of 300 Hor≈øe; whereupon I cau≈øed the Army to be brought into Cappoquin; and the adjacent villages, where they might have ≈øome ≈øhelter from the weather, which hath been very foul,
I repaired unto Cork, to take order for fitting the new armed forces to come unto the Army, intending with them to ≈øit down before Dungarvan; and for that purpo≈øe I am fain fir≈øt to lead away the Army, with all things they are able to carry with them, and having fixed them to bring back the oxen and draught hor≈øes to draw the pieces of battery, all the oxen I have being able to draw no more then two of them at a time. And although I may happen by this means in two or three dayes to get the Ordnance from Cappoquin, to Dungarven, which is but 7 miles; yet I a≈ø≈øure you it wil be impo≈ø≈øible to draw them to any other place till we have draught-hor≈øes and carriages, the want whereof doth exceedingly ob≈øtruct the carrying on of the Service. Upon the fir≈øt news of Col. Temple his coming, I was in great fear that the men come with him would be unwilling to come abroad, becau≈øe I had then no money left, but what was that day to be i≈ø≈øued to the Army in the field, who were paid partly in mony, and partly in provi≈øion; ≈øo as I had no ≈øhift, but to put the Army off two or three dayes for the money, and to give ≈øo much of that (as I found requi≈øite) to furni≈øh out Colonel Temples men; who had not been here 24 hours, when there arrived Richard Smith with the Robert and John of London with 1400 barrels of pea≈øe, and 700 barrels of wheat; and the next morning after I came to Cork, Capt. Swanly the Admiral of the≈øe Seas arrived with 5000 l. in mony, 140 hor≈øe, and 100 foot; ≈øo as now we are in probability ab≈øolutely ma≈øters of the field: And I doubt not, if our ≈øins do not render us yet unfit for ≈øuch mercies, that by the latter end of this Summer all this Province will be reduced; which will be much the better and ≈øooner done, if the
Parliament be plea≈øed to ≈øend a Committee hither, as I have continually de≈øired, that may be con≈øtantly at Cork, to take care of providing for the Army and Garri≈øons, nece≈ø≈øaries for the Artillery, improving of the revenue, and ≈øuch things as cannot be in any mea≈øure well done in my ab≈øence, except I have a Committee to a≈ø≈øi≈øt; and that they may have power for i≈ø≈øuing of monies, and may ≈øee that the things the Army now wants may be brought ≈øea≈øonably to us: which being my duty to repre≈øent to that honourable A≈ø≈øembly, I have here inclo≈øed ≈øent a Li≈øt thereof, and if they plea≈øe to tran≈ømit them unto us, I doubt not but we ≈øhall ea≈øily remove all the difficulties that the Rebels can interpo≈øe between us and the accompli≈øhing of tho≈øe expectations that may be entertained by the State, in recompence of that charge and trouble they have undergone for the re-e≈øtabli≈øhing of the Engli≈øh Intere≈øt, and the truely reformed Religion in this Province; whereunto there ≈øhall be no endeavour wanting that lies in the power of

THe winde hath ≈øtay'd my other Letters till now that the Town and Ca≈øtle of Dungarvan is ≈øurrendered unto me; before which I have lain ≈øince Munday la≈øt, being the 3 of this in≈øtant. And although I plaid upon it 4 days ≈øucce≈ø≈øively with 4 Pieces of Battery, yet was not the place made any way a≈ø≈øaultable thereby, nor indeed much the wor≈øe; all the prejudice we did them being the beating down a Flanker upon the Town-wall, which was lyned with earth, 14 foot high: And as we finde that if
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
they within had not wanted things nece≈ø≈øary for defence thereof, it might have held out a long time; ≈øo we perceive that after the gaining of the Town, the Ca≈øtle might in like manner have proved defen≈øible: Yet we conceiving them not to be of that ≈øtrength, had re≈øolved to give that place no quarter, being it had put us to ≈øo much trouble, le≈øt the giving Conditions to ≈øuch, might be an encouragement to other places to hold out, in expectation of like Conditions at la≈øt. But the want of Carriages had almo≈øt ≈øtarved us, being unable to fetch our provi≈øions 7 miles by any other means, the windes hindering it to come by Sea (as was de≈øigned) then ≈øending the men to fetch them: which being of dangerous con≈øequence, lying neer an enemy, we dur≈øt not do for 3 days together, whereon the Souldiers wanted bread, and had but very little fle≈øh; in≈øomuch as many fell ≈øick, and all grew faint; ≈øo as indeed we thought it a very great ble≈ø≈øing to have the Town and Ca≈øtle ≈øo ≈øurrendred to us upon the inclo≈øed Conditions; although we now finde they were in very ill condition to hold out longer, their Ammunition of all ≈øorts being almo≈øt ≈øpent; whereof they had a good ≈øupply coming by Sea from Waterford; but I gave order to Captain Plunket's Frigot to come and lie in this Harbour, to prevent any relief that way; and ≈øhe happened to arrive (as al≈øo Captain Willoughby in the Non≈øuch) before this Boat of Ammunition, which came within ≈øight of them along the Coa≈øt, but pre≈øently thereupon returned.

This City of Waterford, which is now one of the riche≈øt in this Kingdom, as al≈øo the City of Ca≈øhel, and Town of Clomnel, are each of them in great fear of our approach, and doth ≈ølight all ditches and places of ≈øhelter neer the Towns: But as I did in my la≈øt mention, ≈øo I do now
by experience finde, that I cannot make an Attempt upon any Town, until we be enabled to march with a Train; neither indeed can we put Gari≈øons into any more places, until we have more men: So as I mu≈øt now apply my ≈øelf altogether to the de≈øtroying of the Rebels Quarters, if they do not fight with us, as I believe they will not: for I finde by a Spie that is come to me la≈øt night from Waterford, that they can rai≈øe neither Money or Provi≈øion as yet, to keep an Army together; that therefore their General Glamorgun dares not come to a Rendezvous among≈øt them; that they have great divi≈øions among them≈øelves, which al≈øo keep them from uniting; that many of their Officers and Souldiers are going away with the French and Spani≈øh Agents from Waterford, which I ≈øhall give the Fleet notice of; That Ammunition is ≈øcarce among≈øt them, whereof the greate≈øt plenty is at Waterford, where the Councel pay 2s. per pound for it; That my Lord of Muskerry is now in that City, being employed thither by the Supreme Councel, to borrow money of the Citizens to pay their Army; for the maintenance whereof, they have impo≈øed a Tax of the fourth part of every mans revenue, and a tenth part of per≈øonal e≈øtates in all the Iri≈øh Quarters: That it is there reported, that Catherlogh was taken by Pr ‚Ä¢ ston on the 5 of this in≈øtant; but no certainty thereof: And that there is not yet above 1500 of the Rebels Forces together in any one place. Another Spie came unto me la≈øt night from Fetherd, who confirms that the Rebels are full of Divi≈øions, and cannot rai≈øe means for their Army, which therefore they cannot bring together: So as there is nothing but the defects in our Army, that hinders us (with Gods leave) to do what we would in the Rebels Quarters. And though it be now onely Carriages and
Draught hor≈øes that are wanting to carry on the Service; yet if Supplies of Moneys or Provi≈øions do not arrive before the 10 of June, all that is now here will no longer contribute to our ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, with all the addition that our Contribution can make to it. But we will endeavour to do what we can to live upon the enemy; wherein we hope for a ble≈ø≈øing; not doubting but that Providence which hath hitherto ≈øu≈øtained us, will enable us, either by that or ≈øome other means, to ≈øub≈øi≈øt, till Supplies from thence ≈øhall arrive to us.

Sir, I have been prolix; but it is to give you an account of what I hold my duty to inform that Honourable A≈ø≈øembly of, unto whom I de≈øire to di≈øcharge all the parts thereof that lie in the power of

ORdered by the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, That a Letter of thanks be written to the Lord INCHIQUEEN, and that it be referred to the Committee for the Affairs of IRELAND at Derby-Hou≈øe to prepare this Letter.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øynge Cler. Parl. Dom. Com.
